description.narrative: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capacity for scanning, sense-making, and experimenting for sustainable development solutions in 90 countries.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: 1.1 - 5 new data sources per year 1.2 - 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 - 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 - 5 innovation methods per Action Plan. 2.1 - At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 - At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 - At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 - 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 - 14 new sources of data were introduced
1. edX Platform Data of Bangladeshi and Indian Users (made available by edX to Lab) 2. Data of SSC (Secondary School Certificate) exam candidates learning behavior collected through a custom Learning Management System (LMS) deployed by the Lab 3. Data of social media users on their engagement (Facebook) on Labs ‘Ami Shei Kal Joyi Nari’ video 4. Data of Womens Digital Innovation Hackathon participants learning through post-hack survey 5. Data of disaster and climate change expenditure of 3095 rural households from 10 selected districts 6. Data of Business Process Outsourcing (BPO) employer skills demand and skills gaps (Study completed with 50 companies surveyed) 7. Data of ICT/CSE students on their perspective on micro-credentials (Study completed with 1000+ students surveyed) 8. Data of host community youths employment status and their ICT readiness. 9. Data of community-based tourism on informal employment (profile and evaluation data of beach workers) 10. Data on informal worker - tour guides in Coxs Bazar (training and evaluation data of tour guides) 11. Data on informal employment - boat operators in Bandarban (profile and evaluation data of boat operators) 12. Data on informal employment - Jeep drives in Bandarban (training and evaluation data) 13. Data on unemployed rural women in host community (socio-economic, poverty, income and demographic data) 14. Multi-dimensional poverty index data - specialized in social safety-net data and World Bank Group socio-economic data)
1.2 - 8 different type of data sources (MOOC usage data, LMS data, social media data, Citizen generated data, primary survey data, secondary survey data, GIS data, interviews)
1.3 - 39 new potential solutions identified and documented in the Solutions Platform.
1.4 - 12 innovation methods were used for the 2 Action Plans 1. Informality Patters in Bangladesh - Behaviorial Insights, Data Visualization, System Thinking, Participatory Needs Assessment. 2. Coastal Belt IGA - Behavioral Insights, Collective Intelligence, Micro Narratives, Randomized Controlled Trials, System Thinking. 3. YEAPI-B - Co-creation, Future Analysis, Hackathons, Horizon Scanning, Sensemaking.
2.1 - 7 blogs published 1. Generating informal employment opportunities for local residents in tourism: The case of Tangail district of Bangladesh 2. Accelerating Equitable E-Learning in Bangladesh 3. Financing disaster-induced expenses: findings from a Household Expenditure Survey in Bangladesh 4. Women’s Digital Innovation Hackathon 5. Learning from Exploration: Entrepreneurship instilling changemaking in the future minds of Bangladesh 6. Thanchi: Rising star of Community-based Tourism 7. Through our lens:Community-based Tourism unlocking the potentials of informal employment opportunities in Thanchi (Bangladesh)
2.2 - 100% learning challenges have the public sector or other partners as counterpart 1. Informality Patterns in Bangladesh - Bangladesh Tourism Board, Local Government, ICT Division. 2. Coastal Belt IGA Opportunities for Poverty Reduction in Bangladesh - GED, Womens Chamber of Commerce, Tour Operators Association, Tourist Police, Coxs Bazar Chamber of Commerce, Jahangirnagar University, Dhaka University. 3. e-Learning Pilot Project - Volunteers Associaton for Bangladresh 4. Whole of Society approach in Tourism - Bangladesh Tourism Board, CHT Local Government. 5. YEAPI-B - edX, Reaktor, Women in Digital, Univeristy of Helsinki, UNLEASH Innovation Lab
2.3 - Three government entity/partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods 1. Bangladesh Tourism Board 2. Tourist Police 3. Chittagong Hill Tracts Local Government
2.4 - 83% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects 1. Mutual Fund support for LoGIC project 2. Grant Facility support for SWM project 3. Toursim & Informality support for SID CHT Project 4. Blue Economy support for CCP project 5. NICE platform experiment support for a2i project.
3.1 - 100% achieved (48+). The lab has interacted at least once a week with another lab in the network. Majority of interactions were with labs in Asia and other labs across the network working on similar challenges and innovation methods as Bangladesh.
3.2 - 100% achieved. At least 25% of information shared by Bangladesh AccLab across the network were on methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related (UNDP Womens Digital Innovation Hackathon, YEAPI-B & edX collaboration).
3.3 - Approximately 50% acheived. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work was featured periodically in the Country Office Social Media channels and tagged UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts over the year 2021.
Approximately 50% acheived. The Lab team had engaged periodically across social media conversations related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account over the year 2021.
3.4 - The lab connected its publications to local development ecosystem through social media for several interventions (Blogs, Hackathon, Ami Shei Kal Joyi Nari video, Behaviorial Insights, ICT Literacy, First-aid, Tour training, Photography, Safe drive, Prothom Alo and CPD).
The Lab engaged 13 new relevant local and individual social media profiles (new artists on-boarded for Ami Shei Kal Joyi Nari video included singers and artists - Amzad Hossain, Elita Karim, Palbasha Siddique, Armeen Musa, Tashfee, Nahar, Johan Alamgir, D-rockstar Shuvo, Labik Kamal, Moktadir Dewan, Sayon Mansang, MG Kibria), and 3 institutional profiles - Women in Digital (@WID_Network) and UNLEASH (@UNLEASHlab).

1.1 - 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 - 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 - 6 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 - 2 innovation methods per Action Plan 2.1 - 1 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 - At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.3 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 - The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. 3.2 - 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least once per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 - Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

The lab was established at the end of 2020 with the last member joining on 01 November. This did not allow much time for the lab to work towards the targets set for Year 1. Based on the 100 Days Action Plan and activities, the lab was able to achieve the following results:
1.1 - 3 new sources of data were introduced (Digital Data for Development database of World Bank Group and LinkedIn, ADB’s Real-Time Assessment Using Bangladesh and Sri Lanka Online Job Portals, Social Media Engagement Data for AccLab’s Violence Against Women video) 1.2 - 3 different type of data sources (LinkedIn Data, BDJobs Job-Portal Data, and Social Media Engagement Data) 1.3 - The lab was able to identify 6 new potential solutions during 3 months in 2020 (VAW Video, One-Stop Service Centre for Women Entrepreneurs in Host Community, Youth Employment Accelerator Program Initiative – Bangladesh, Ethnic Community Based Tourism in Cox’s Bazaar, Mutual Fund for LoGIC, Employment in Dry Fish Industry) 1.4 - 5 innovation methods were used for the 2 Action Plans (Foresight, Future Analysis, Sensemaking, Positive Deviance, Horizon Scanning)
2.1 - 1 media post published (‘Ami Shei Kal Joyi Nari’ video on Violence Against Women) 2.2 - One government entity/partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods (Prime Minister’s Office) 2.3 - 100% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects (Mutual Fund for LoGIC project, Grant Facility for SWM project, Blue Economy for CCP project). 3.1 - The lab has interacted at least once a week with another lab in the network. Majority of interactions were with labs in South Asia and other labs across the network working on similar frontier challenges as Bangladesh. 3.2 - At least 5% of information shared by Bangladesh AccLab across the network were on methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 - The Accelerator Lab Network´s work was featured at least once per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team had engaged at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 - The lab connected its publications to local development ecosystem through social media (Prothom Alo and CPD). It also identified and engaged over 5 new relevant local social media profiles (new artists on-boarded for VAW video).
